importance: This paper is important because **it addresses a critical limitation of existing open-vocabulary action recognition (OVAR) methods: their vulnerability to noisy user-provided text descriptions.** By proposing a novel framework that handles noisy inputs, this research enhances the real-world applicability of OVAR.  It opens up new avenues for research into robust multimodal learning and improves the accuracy and reliability of action recognition systems. The findings are highly relevant to researchers working on vision-language models and video understanding.
summary: DENOISER improves open-vocabulary action recognition by addressing noisy text descriptions via a novel generative-discriminative framework, boosting real-world applicability.
takeaways: Existing open-vocabulary action recognition methods struggle with noisy text descriptions.
The proposed DENOISER framework effectively handles noisy text descriptions by iteratively refining them using visual and textual information.
DENOISER significantly improves the robustness and accuracy of open-vocabulary action recognition, outperforming existing methods.
tldr:
Open-Vocabulary Action Recognition (OVAR) is crucial for computer vision but suffers from a major drawback: real-world text descriptions are often noisy (misspellings, typos).  Existing OVAR models are highly sensitive to these errors, significantly hindering their accuracy and practical use. This paper identifies the noise problem and its impact on existing methods' performance. 
The paper introduces DENOISER, a novel framework that tackles noisy OVAR. DENOISER uses a two-stage approach: first, it denoises the noisy text descriptions using a generative model that incorporates both visual and textual information to produce more accurate text candidates.  Second, it uses a standard OVAR model to classify the video based on the improved text descriptions.  Through iterative refinement between the denoising and classification steps, DENOISER achieves significantly improved accuracy and robustness compared to existing methods, making OVAR more practical for real-world applications.
